Introduction

Getting into cloud computing can feel like a lot at first. As a college student, I’ve been figuring it out step by step—learning from mistakes, completing projects, and gaining a better understanding of what’s possible in tech. In this post, I’m sharing the projects I’ve worked on, what I’ve learned, and where I want to go from here.

Finding My Way to Cloud Computing

At first, I wasn’t sure what part of IT I wanted to focus on. I looked into help desk roles, cybersecurity, and even project management. But once I started learning about cloud computing, it just clicked. The idea of being able to build scalable, powerful systems without needing physical hardware was exciting. Plus, it feels like there’s always something new to learn in this field.

Projects I’ve Completed

1. Hosting a Static Website on AWS S3

This was my first real project, and it was a great intro to cloud computing. I created a static website and hosted it on AWS S3. Along the way, I figured out:

  • How to set up an S3 bucket for hosting.
  • Fixed issues with file structures and index.html.
  • Configured public access to make the site live.

Seeing the site up and running at http://codepen-test-website.s3-website.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/ was super rewarding. It made me realize how quickly you can bring ideas to life in the cloud.

2. Building this Personal Blog with AWS Lightsail

This one’s in progress, but I’ve already learned a lot. I’m setting up a WordPress blog on AWS Lightsail, which has helped me get into managing virtual servers. Here’s what I’ve been doing so far:

  • Spinning up a Lightsail instance and configuring it for WordPress.
  • Setting up a custom domain and working on securing it with HTTPS.
  • Customizing the blog to make it my own.

This project has shown me how cloud services can simplify hosting while still letting you dive into the technical details when needed.

Title: My Journey Into Cloud Computing: A College Student’s Perspective

Introduction

Getting into cloud computing can feel like a lot at first. As a college student, I’ve been figuring it out step by step—learning from mistakes, completing projects, and gaining a better understanding of what’s possible in tech. Finding My Way to Cloud Computing

At first, I wasn’t sure what part of IT I wanted to focus on. I looked into help desk roles, cybersecurity, and even project management. But once I started learning about cloud computing, it just clicked. The idea of being able to build scalable, powerful systems without needing physical hardware was exciting. Plus, it feels like there’s always something new to learn in this field.

Projects I’ve Completed

1. Hosting a Static Website on AWS S3

This was my first real project, and it was a great intro to cloud computing. I created a static website and hosted it on AWS S3. Along the way, I figured out:

  • How to set up an S3 bucket for hosting.
  • Fixed issues with file structures and index.html.
  • Configured public access to make the site live.

Seeing the site up and running at http://codepen-test-website.s3-website.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/ was super rewarding. It made me realize how quickly you can bring ideas to life in the cloud.

2. Building a Personal Blog with AWS Lightsail

This one’s in progress, but I’ve already learned a lot. I’m setting up a WordPress blog on AWS Lightsail, which has helped me get into managing virtual servers. Here’s what I’ve been doing so far:

  • Spinning up a Lightsail instance and configuring it for WordPress.
  • Setting up a custom domain and working on securing it with HTTPS.
  • Customizing the blog to make it my own.

This project has shown me how cloud services can simplify hosting while still letting you dive into the technical details when needed.

3. Breaking Down Red Team Attacks

One of my most interesting experiences was a group project where we analyzed Red Team Attack strategies. Even though it wasn’t strictly cloud-focused, it gave me a lot of insight into vulnerabilities and defenses—something that’s super relevant to cloud security. My role involved:

  • Researching and explaining attack methods to my team.
  • Contributing ideas for improving security defenses.
  • Getting a better understanding of how attackers think.

This project showed me the importance of teamwork and how collaboration leads to better results.

What I Enjoy About the Cloud

For me, the best part of cloud computing is how hands-on it is. Whether it’s hosting a website or setting up a blog, you’re always solving real problems and seeing the results immediately. It’s also a field where you’re constantly learning, which keeps things interesting.
